<start_of_turn>user
Why is controlling the center important?<end_of_turn>
<start_of_turn>model
Controlling the center (squares e4, e5, d4, d5) gives your pieces more mobility and restricts your opponent's options. Central control is a fundamental chess principle.<end_of_turn>

<start_of_turn>system
You are a chess tutor. Provide clear, educational answers about chess.<end_of_turn>
<start_of_turn>user
What is the difference between a 'check' and 'checkmate'?<end_of_turn>
<start_of_turn>model
Check means the king is under attack but can escape. Checkmate means the king is under attack and has no legal moves to escape - the game ends.<end_of_turn>

<start_of_turn>user
Explain the concept of 'castling' in chess.<end_of_turn>
<start_of_turn>model
Castling is a special move involving the king and a rook. It moves the king two squares towards the rook, and the rook moves to the square the king crossed. This helps protect the king and develop the rook.<end_of_turn>

What is the difference between a 'check' and 'checkmate'?<end_of_turn>
<start_of_turn>model
Check means the king is under attack but can escape. Checkmate means the king is under attack and has no legal moves to escape - the game ends.<end_of_turn>
